Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The neurocognitive bases of effective emotional conflict resolution

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research consisted of three main parts. The first part consists of assisting with an fMRI research of visual perception in patients with schizophrenia and healthy normal subjects. We presented fantasy-like images and real life-like images to both groups of participants and compare their BOLD (brain oxygenation level dependent) activity between the two conditions as well as groups. I was mainly involved in the data collection phase and the data collection phase is not completely over yet, hence I did not readily participate in the analysis of the dataset but I do anticipate being involved in the analysis and write-up of the experiment at the end of the data collection.

          The second part of my research consisted of assisting with a behavioral experiment using a virtual reality interface. The experiment involved having participants perform a mock public speaking in front of realistic looking 3D avatar audiences that were projected to their visual field using HMD goggles. Each participant’s eye gaze was quantified using an eye-tracking mechanism attached to the HMD goggles. Even though the experiment was simplistic, combining the virtual reality interface with eye-tracking technology made it a novel research. My task was to adapt each participants to the virtual reality system and calibrate the eye-tracker to each individual’s eye position so that the tracking mechanism could collect accurate and consistent eye-tracking data. In relations to this I was able to think of ways to utilize the virtual reality system to develop a social cognition experiment. The system provides a realistic virtual environment in which users or experiment participants can immerse themselves into the virtual environment. This allows for a stronger and more potent manipulation of social stimuli. Using facial expression of avatars for example, one could evoke a stronger emotional reaction from the users. This is a very helpful insight for me personally since I am very interested pursuing research related to subjective emotional experience.

          The third part of my research was writing up an invited review chapter with Dr. Jae-jin Kim about the utility of virtual reality system for the purpose of assessing social skills in patients with mental health problems. This was a very fitting extension to my hands-on experience running virtual reality behavioral experiments with social phobia patients. I plan on continuing this even after leaving Korea for a timely submission of the manuscript for publication. This will act as a nice continuity that will keep my communication connected to Dr. Kim’s lab in Korea. I would like to express my gratitude to Dr. Kim for his willingness to include me as a co-author on his review chapter.

In addition to the direct research experience during my stay at Yonsei severance hospital in Seoul, I was also able to learn and share my academic ideas and research-related knowledge and skills with lab members in Dr. Kim’s lab over regular lab meetings as well as unofficial meetings. Every Monday evening Dr. Kim had a lab research meeting where a few people presented their progress on research and new research ideas. The first week I came, I presented my present research back at Vanderbilt and received numerous feedbacks that were useful in restructuring my ideas about the research I have been conducting in Nashville. Also recently, I did another PowerPoint presentation of a new research idea based on my exposure to the social cognition study using the virtual reality system. Through this presentation during the lab meeting, I was again able to receive valuable input on the specifics as well as the theoretical background of the hypothesis I had.
